title: (x) 1930s slab serif - Memphis (pre-digital w/ alternates) {Mike Yanega}
content:
This is from an 1920s or 30s era cigar packaging -- pulled from a Dover book on Art Deco era advertising. Any ideas on the closest digital version I could find?   
   
Thanks.   
   
Troy ![type sample](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518051009im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/20204.jpg)
author: dctroy

comments.content: Dover has a [series of cds](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518051009/http:/store.doverpublications.com/by-subject-art-dover-electronic-display-fonts-series--cd-rom-.html) with display fonts compiled by Dan X. Solo. The font you want might be on one of them -- unfortunately, I haven't found an easy way to know exactly what's on there. You might just have to go to a bookstore or art supplies store and look at them in person. Hope that isn't a wild-goose chase.

I don't think the font is in one of the Solotype disks. I got a listing once of what was on them. Anyway, I think this typeface is Linotype Memphis, which had identical alternate characters to the A & M shown here. See attached scan from 1930's Linotype Catalog. However, I can't see any evidence that the digital version of Memphis has these characters. ![Memphis scan](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518051009im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/20228.gif)

The sample is surely Memphis.   
   
Does anyone know how Memphis was digitized? It seems that a lot of the original character of the face was changed, the lowercase g was substituted with its alternate, the numerals were also altered. Anyone know why?
